title: Supply Chain Routing Optimization
problem: A global logistics company needed to optimize routing for 500+ delivery vehicles across multiple cities, facing exponential complexity with classical solvers.
whatWasTested: Hybrid quantum-classical algorithms using D-Wave quantum annealing and classical MILP solvers in parallel.

worked: Quantum-inspired methods matched classical performance on medium-scale problems
Hybrid approach reduced solution time by 35% on specific problem instances
Identified problem structures particularly suited to quantum approaches
didNotWork: Pure quantum solutions struggled with real-world constraints
Hardware limitations restricted problem size to 200 variables
Integration with existing systems required significant engineering

businessInsight: Hybrid approaches are viable for pilot-scale problems; full quantum advantage remains future-facing. The client now has a clear roadmap for scaling as hardware improves.

title: Portfolio Optimization Pilot
problem: An asset management firm wanted to test quantum approaches for multi-asset portfolio optimization with complex constraints.
whatWasTested: Variational quantum eigensolver (VQE) and QAOA algorithms on IBM Quantum hardware, compared against classical quadratic programming.

worked: Successfully encoded portfolio optimization as QUBO problem
Demonstrated quantum workflow integration with existing risk systems
Team gained hands-on quantum computing experience
didNotWork: Current quantum hardware too noisy for production use
Classical solvers outperformed quantum on all tested problem sizes
High overhead for error mitigation reduced practical speedup

businessInsight: Quantum portfolio optimization is not ready for production, but the pilot built internal capabilities and established a monitoring framework for future hardware improvements.

title: Molecular Simulation for Drug Discovery
problem: A pharmaceutical company sought to accelerate molecular property prediction for early-stage drug candidates.
whatWasTested: Quantum chemistry simulations using PennyLane and Qiskit, focusing on small molecule ground state energy calculations.

worked: Accurate simulation of molecules up to 12 qubits
Established benchmark framework for quantum vs classical chemistry methods
Identified specific molecular structures suited for near-term quantum advantage
didNotWork: Larger, drug-relevant molecules exceeded current qubit capacity
Noise in current hardware limited accuracy for precise predictions
Classical density functional theory remained more practical for most use cases

businessInsight: Quantum chemistry shows promise for specific small-molecule problems. The client is now monitoring hardware progress and has identified target molecules for future quantum simulations.
